Note: The capital letter represents the dominant allele and the lowercase letter represents the recessive allele. When the genotype contains a mix of capital and lowercase letters, it means the individual is heterozygous for that allele. In a three-point test cross, the dominant allele always shows up as dominant, so we can use the phenotype of the offspring to determine the allele in the middle. If the offspring are heterozygous, we can look at the phenotype of the offspring to determine the dominant and recessive alleles. If the offspring are all homozygous, we can assume that both parents were homozygous for the same allele and the allele in the middle is the opposite allele.
